docs.snippet: Despite Monday’s ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, the issue remains that not every athlete’s anatomy and physiology fits society’s definition of man and woman....
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite Monday’s ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, the issue remains that not every athlete’s anatomy and physiology fits society’s definition of man and woman.
docs.abstract: Juliet Macur Sports of The Times column congratulates Indian sprinter Dutee Chand, who refused to take measures to make her body produce less testosterone in order to be allowed to compete as a woman; discusses problems faced by IAAF in creating eligibility standards for female athletes with hyperandrogenism.

headline.main: The Line Between Male and Female Athletes Remains Blurred
headline.print_headline: Despite Sprinter’s Legal Triumph, Thorny Issue Isn’t Over

docs.snippet: Athletes who participate as females in junior competitions, and continue to do so at the senior level, should not have their eligibility questioned....
docs.lead_paragraph: Athletes who participate as females in junior competitions, and continue to do so at the senior level, should not have their eligibility questioned.

headline.main: Who Should Be Allowed to Compete as a Female Athlete?

docs.snippet: There are about 15 to 20 graduates of Haverford, an N.C.A.A. Division III college, working in prominent baseball-related jobs, as front-office executives, agents and talent evaluators....
docs.lead_paragraph: There are about 15 to 20 graduates of Haverford, an N.C.A.A. Division III college, working in prominent baseball-related jobs, as front-office executives, agents and talent evaluators.
docs.abstract: Unusual number of front-office executives, agents and talent evaluators in major league baseball are graduates of Haverford College, Division III school outside Philadelphia that offers no athletic scholarships or sports-related majors; reasons for phenomenon are complex and varied.

headline.main: Tiny Haverford College an Unlikely Pipeline to Major League Baseball’s Front Offices
headline.print_headline: An Unlikely Pipeline to Front Offices

docs.snippet: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV will face a shortage of new products in North America over the next 18 months, especially hot-selling trucks and crossover vehicles, according to three sources familiar with the company's plans....

docs.snippet: Japanese organizers apologized to the IOC on Wednesday over the scrapping of the original plans for the Olympic stadium and delivered assurances that the new venue will be ready in time for the 2020 Games....

headline.main: Tokyo Olympic Chief Apologizes to IOC Over Stadium Change

docs.snippet: Researchers in Denmark recently developed a new approach to intense interval training that could appeal even to those of us who, until now, have been disinclined to push ourselves during exercise....

headline.main: A Way to Get Fit and Also Have Fun

docs.snippet: The Japanese business newspaper hopes that the $1.3 billion purchase will give it a trophy that can compete with major papers in Europe and America....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Japanese business newspaper hopes that the $1.3 billion purchase will give it a trophy that can compete with major papers in Europe and America.
docs.abstract: Interviews with current and former Nikkei journalists reveal that many have doubts about paper's acquisition of The Financial Times; say purchase, part of president Naotoshi Okada's vision for expanding global influence of company, will amount to mere trophy asset; others say it offers potential for Nikkei to capitalize on British paper's international reporting and online distribution.

headline.main: Nikkei Vies for Global Clout With Splurge on The Financial Times
headline.print_headline: Nikkei Vies for Global Clout by Splurging on Pink Trophy
